newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan consumer spending gradually recovering--govt.
newsitem.headline: Japan consumer spending gradually recovering--govt.

text.p: Japan's consumer spending is gradually recovering despite a large drop in household spending in June from a year earlier, an official of the government's Management and Coordination Agency told reporters on Tuesday.
"The recovery in consumer spending, although it is gradual, remains firm," the official said.
The agency said earlier that household spending had fallen a real 4.7 percent in June from the same month last year, the largest drop since November 1974, when it fell 5.9 percent.

But the official said a number of special factors had pushed down the June figure and that household spending for the January-June period, which fell 0.2 percent from the same period last year, was "a reasonable result".
He said taking account of the effect of last year having been a leap year, the comparison for January-June this year might otherwise have been a positive figure.
He added that household spending had shown falls on a half-yearly basis since the latter half of 1992, with the exception of the first half of last year.

June household spending had fallen due to bad weather, in particular two typhoons which had fallen on weekends, as well as a lingering fall-off in demand after the rise in the sales tax on April 1. The tax was raised to five percent from three percent.
